title: Redpath Sugar Refinery
note: Construction began on the refinery in 1854. In 1871, George Drummond, manager of the refinery, designed and built a new wing east of the existing buildings. After closing in 1876 due to a depression, the refinery reopened in 1879 and began expansion and modernisation of its facilities. A new refinery was built in 1892. The refinery complex was reconstructed and expanded from 1908 to 1912. In 1907, the upper brickwork floors of the original refinery building were demolished; the two lower floors, of solid stone masonry, were retained. From 1908 to 1909, the demolished floors were replaced by a new structure similar to the original but higher by one floor at its centre, and new machinery was installed. The machinery of the complex was overhauled from 1925 to 1927; the old boiler house was demolished in 1926 and replaced with a new one. The refinery closed in 1979 and in 1982 the site was subject to partial demolition. In 1999 controversy arose over proposals to convert refinery into condominiums.
